ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Do you mean something like http://philip.html5.org/data/charsets.html ?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:19): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I don't think anyone has any data like that
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:20): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: That data there should be enough to work from
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:20): Oh, right, I have data like that - that was convenient
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:21): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:21): I'd be interested in a bigger less bias sample, though
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:21): (Seeming dmoz is bias towards English)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:22): I don't think the concept of "less bias" exists
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:22): You can just choose the direction in which you want the bias to be
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:22): Ooh, a blizzard
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:23): (dmoz is definitely biased towards English, and I think it's also biased towards western European)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:24): (so it's really bad for e.g. Chinese sites)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:27): Whoops
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:27): That's because '.' was a regexp
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:27): If I make it \. then there's 0
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:27): (The other numbers don't change much)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:28): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Yeah, that's my problem.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:28): What's ZH?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:28): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, interesting
99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e (16:29): thinks those *.jp sites are years old

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:29): (that Flash player they are using is also really cool btw)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:30): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Alexa's list might be better, since it's got ~20K for *.cn (and similar for *.jp and *.uk)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:31): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: But do you have data for that? :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:31): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: (though it only lists sites rather than pages, so it's entirely biased towards the initial entry pages)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:32): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: No, but you could easily download the list and then download a few thousand .cn pages and search them for patterns :-)

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:39): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: there would be benefit of having separate sets for different countries. I had this discussion with 15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d about the mama too.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:40): The issue is how to create these sets

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:41): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: The problem is that it would encourage comparison between datasets, and comparisons are very dangerous because you're usually comparing the bias of the samples rather than real differences
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:41): There is also all the invisible Web. The one behind passwd or intranets
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:42): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yes indeed, you have to always give the context of your studies, plus a bit of error calculations.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:42): There is nothing *true* in sample surveys, just giving you hints but not certainty
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:43): has suddenly a big wave of astrophysical studies and research coming back to his head

15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (16:44): With publicly available sets, the burden of determining the set is pretty much off the entity that is doing the analysis. Any other set requires a lot of extra legwork, both in getting and describing the additional URLs, examining its bias. Not to say that publicly available sets don't have bias, it is just that they are more easily documented.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:45): can someone quickly tell me whether the character that e.g. &euml; represents can have multiple Unicode representations?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:45): e.g. its own character and one using two characters that combine into one?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:45): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: Error calculations don't seem especially helpful here - I can say "(4.56+/-0.07)% of pages in dmoz.org have property P" based on the sample size, but that says nothing meaningful about other data sets (e.g. dmoz.org yesterday or tomorrow, or some other selection of pages)
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: again context‚Ä¶ and calculation of confidence depending on your data set.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: What is euml?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:48): data:text/html,&euml;
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Yes, it has at least two representations
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:48): thx
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:49): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: Yeah, I could find that. I don't however know Unicode codepoints off the top of my head. :)
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (16:56): So, is there a way to use available URL sets that is both reproduceable and has the ability to improve the set in ways that are statistically meaningful?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:56): ah the combining diaresis is 0308
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:56): and the diaresis is 00A8
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:57): 15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d: as a downloaded set or as an accessible set ?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:57): will have to explain that

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (16:59): an URL set is "biological". It changes in time, because of the nature of the Web. So for example to compare the results of two different tools, we need a downloaded dated set of URIs and their content (and metadata going with it)

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:01): Then there is the quality of the set‚Ä¶ and here same kind of issues than in astrophysics when I was doing star fields research. At a point you have to select the stars, because if you pick up randomly, you get many interesting stats, but not really usable in a scientific way
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:02): What if you balance it between selected and random?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:02): I guess the balanced set helps you to test the quality of the random
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:03): s/balanced/selected/

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:20): the selected set helps you to test hypothesis in a controlled environment. For example, new Web sites released by Web agencies (recent contracts) to see what are the new professional practices.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:22): on a Japanese only set and on a few years, we could also see for example if people are switching to utf-8 or not.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:22): without necessary knowing if it's a local choice or a constraints of the tools to produce Web sites.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:24): 15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d: did you play with different user agent strings for the MAMA, faking the string to see the variability?
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:28): That's been on my list of things to do. I played around with it once with the Alexa Top 1000 and had interesting results, but they were hard to interpret.
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:28): I've never come up with the perfect way to compare the results between UA strings.
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:28): I kept finding different things that were variable between versions.
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:32): I pulled content using the latest UAs from Opera, FF, and MSIE, as well as the forthcoming Opera UA, as well as a UA called "foo" for comparison. 8-}
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:36): 15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d: hehe. The Power of Foo! known by old monks in China for generations. They tackle issues on bad Web pages.
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:37): yes, they are the experts in Kung Foo

15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:38): I found that I had to ignore both IMG references and hyperlink HREFs, because many sites randomize the arguments for them to aid tracking...it just makes the analysis job harder. ;-}
15acf9951f4c900b4605265783e17a5d (17:40): At a certain point I was really wondering if what I was deleting was too crucial to throw away. I'm not sure of the answer to that.
